TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesday: A week of Experimental Testing

Articles.Content:
Actually, I have a suggestion regarding the turbofans now:

Make them toggleable.

They can be on by default for realism / educational purposes, but with a tweak menu button to hide them when we're building something unconventional or want the (small) FPS savings.

Hmm? Hmm? All in favor? Hmmm? 8D

Yea im definatly thinking kerbal submarine program It would be great if Scot Manly revisits this after 1.05/1.1 comes out

Looking forward to steam controller support! And i think the new engines look fantastic! Im down with change if it makes things feel more realistic

Actually, I have a suggestion regarding the turbofans now:

Make them toggleable.

They can be on by default for realism / educational purposes, but with a tweak menu button to hide them when we're building something unconventional or want the (small) FPS savings.

Hmm? Hmm? All in favor? Hmmm? 8D

LUDICROUS!!! What happens next, procedural fuel tanks? It'll be the end of creativity, I tell you!

I want the new Jet model to be tweakable AT LEAST. Remember, the rocket engines get a flat bottom and I'm pretty IRL they go a fair bit further in the structure of the rocket.

Please, Squad, please, please, please make it tweakable!

YargJay9991

PS. Do devs actually read this stuff? Just curious, not furious...

I want the new Jet model to be tweakable AT LEAST. Remember, the rocket engines get a flat bottom and I'm pretty IRL they go a fair bit further in the structure of the rocket.
Depends entirely on the engine. Skipper, Mainsail, LVT-30 and -45 are all where they should be, roughly. 909 could be inside the tank maybe a tiny bit, 48-7S is inside the tank for sure.

Of course weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve encountered various bugs during experimentals, one particularly quirky one was where the fog from being underwater would persist in the map view, making Kerbin look particularly mystical!
the fog from being underwater would persist in the map view
being underwater
This sounds suspiciously like implying submarines are possible. That would be ... sublime.
Speaking of experiments, one little Ã¢â‚¬ËœexperimentÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been testing is an inner turbine model for the jet engines. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s placed at opposite the jet nozzles and will just clip into other parts when attached. The parts basically handle the same as before, but give a better representation of what jet engines actually are, being more than just a nozzle with a hole that produces .flames. Also it adds a logical explanation for their COM offset. We advise you to make sure youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re sat down before you click this link.
This is very, very welcome in KSP. Thank you for working on this.

Mind you, I never thought about the impact on VTOLs. Hmmm...it's not an easy problem to solve without significantly modifying or reworking how jet engines work in KSP. Planes like the Harrier and F35-B have the engine horizontally and the nozzles able to turn.

Still, anything is better than a part having a CoM outside itself, in my view.

  • Decouplers (or any staging part) can be set to have their staging
    toggleable;

This sounds dead handy, I think something like it has been widely asked for. Once or twice I've used decouplers for purely structural purposes, so making sure they're not stageable would be a bit of extra safety.
KSP has usually been regarded as nearly impossible to play with anything other than a keyboard and mouse
By who? I've been flying planes with a 360 pad for ages. Though I'll admit I still need to reach for the keyboard sometimes, but with a better assistant program to support button combinations I could probably do away with that. I've never looked at VAB stuff mind.

In summary, this all sounds like a lot of awesome features. But...but...I care more about bugfixes and performance improvements, and I think I'm not alone in that. New features almost surely mean new bugs, and may mean new performance hits too.

Tweakable would certainly be fine, if you can do that. I've never seen a tweakable turn off part of a model. But then again, I don't really know how that stuff works. However, if you made it tweakable, you could just make it disappear after it is attached to the node and reappear when it gets taken back off the node, those who want it there wouldn't be able to tell the difference anyway, because it doesn't do anything.
this is SO COOL

Chris (Porkjet) meanwhile has been going over some details: polishing up textures, improving exhaust effects, creating heat animation and fixing various smaller issues, directed by the ever-watchful eyes of the experimental testers. Speaking of experiments, one little Ã¢â‚¬ËœexperimentÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been testing is an inner turbine model for the jet engines. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s placed at opposite the jet nozzles and will just clip into other parts when attached. The parts basically handle the same as before, but give a better representation of what jet engines actually are, being more than just a nozzle with a hole that produces .flames. Also it adds a logical explanation for their COM offset.

I'm on the fence about this change. On one hand, it makes sense, and it looks cool. On the other hand, a lot of ships already rely on the short engines - most VTOL designs would be wrecked by this change, for example. Now that wouldn't be such a big deal if you gave us a stock hinge...
I didn't think that the turbine would get so much flak (no pun intended ). I like the turbine. Everything in this update is awesome .

Well guys! I like those turbine. that's all I have to say.

So 1.1 is aimed to be out before Christmas. guess I have to finally visit Duna within the next few week.

Edited November 4, 2015 by Hary R
misspell something

Garbage like something that has absolutely zero gameplay value. They worked just fine without them. All it does is remove functionality, and not add anything.

Agreed. It certainly kills some little athmo dropship designs I had planned.

Cupcake...

Another week of lots of work done. Go team!

I must say though I'm also in the "not sure camp" on the fan-thingie.

Of course jets have an engine that's much bigger than the actual nozzle, but there's such a things as angled nozzles.

For the same reason I am still opposed to the offset CG of the jets. A win-win-situation would have been to add the weight of the engine to whatever part it was attached to, like the way heatshields were implemented when they first came out.

In the end though, I will adapt and build stuff some other way.

After all, it's hard to please everyone.

Keep it up Squad!

<figure class="tmblr-full" data-orig-height="92" data-orig-width="480">

</figure>

ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s placed at opposite the jet nozzles and will just clip into other parts when attached. The parts basically handle the same as before, but give a better representation of what jet engines actually are, being more than just a nozzle with a hole that produces .flames. Also it adds a logical explanation for their COM offset. We advise you to make sure youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re sat down before you click this link.

omg this one is so cool!

but (there's always a but), i think you should make it switchable in the VAB UI..

or several old designs will get screwed (like part of the enging going outside the fuselage )

Also it adds a logical explanation for their COM offset

More logical would be to increase mass of air intakes and decrease mass of jet engines, so CoM would be on middle no matter what we put between those two parts

I really really planned to avoid KSP until 1.1... i was sure to succeed after last weeks newsletter... Now you are ruining everything... I will play 1.0.5... Damn...

Awesome work guys!

With the Fallout 4 release ahead (sorry no 1.0.5 for me),i would be soooo happpy to see a ksp 1.1 for x-mas

Edited November 4, 2015 by StainX

First the wheesley gets nerfed

Then the exhaust-ground interaction brought tons of lag

Then the wheesley got nerfed again

Now there's a giant vtol-killer sticking out of all the jets.

What do Squad have against VTOLs?

Also, real life jets don't always have the nozzle aligned with the turbine - look at the Pegasus onthe Harrier. IMo, although it may look nice in the editor on some designs, turbines would just take away options without really adding any realism or options.

update is looking pretty good

on the subject of the jets: one more for the "not sure" camp. I like the idea of trying to better convey the idea of how jet engines actually look/work, but like so many others have mentioned before me: it does mess with designs that rely on short engines and VTOL designs that have them pointed downwards. In real life there are engineering options that allow for the exhaust of the engine to not be in line with the turbine.

As for how to incorporate this into the game, i'm not entirely sure. Making the turbine part of the engine toggle-able might do it. I need to think on this one a bit more before I can make any definitive calls.

side note: I really don't like giving such a nonplussed answer to something the devs seem to be quite hyped about ... Could we get a bit more information about this feature so we form a more educated opinion? (and possibly get more hyped if our VTOL/design worries are put at ease)

EDIT: after giving the devnotes another read I noticed this sentence in particular regarding the jet engines:

The parts basically handle the same as before, but give a better representation of what jet engines actually are, ...

so now for the million dollar question: does "basically handle the same as before" mean we can still use them on VTOL's and short-engine designs?

Edited November 4, 2015 by Cirocco

How do I really feel?

Changes to an existing part will make some of my existing designs unworkable. Particularly where I used a part for a purpose other than intended.

The Jet engine, for instance, I used as a VTOL (Vertical Take Off and Landing) engine and to help with problems of Centre Of Mass on rovers and such. Sometimes just as an aesthetic.

At first this worried me a little.

But to be fair, some of those craft of mine haven't seen the light of day in a long time.

They were fun to build actually spent a few days designing a single model with a lot of them and I enjoyed playing with them at the time but they were saved and sit in what is basically an archive.

I probably played with them for less time than it took to make them.

I rarely get the urge to bring out an older model and prefer to make something new.

The new parts and water dynamics will certainly give me that opportunity.

I love my VTOL craft, my rovers, my space planes and my rockets.

I loved making them and using them for the missions they were designed for. Then I save them. Put them away, at it were.

When a similar mission comes along I think , "I made something that might be good for this mission" and I may load it and look at it.

Do I use it? No. I start again. "Only this time it will be better." even though often it isn't so much better as different.

I think regardless of the parts used, I will aim for realism with an aesthetic flair. I will imagine the commander of the mission making suggestions to make his job easier. Likewise with the engineer and the science team. And during missions I will imagine comments from the crew.

I have enjoyed all my missions.They made me feel something. Even those that didn't end well. The feelings weren't always pleasant. The rescue missions, if there was someone left to rescue when a mission went badly. A whole new emotional experience.

Changes have been made.

More changes will follow.

My old designs are already redundant.

I need to think of different designs with different abilities and constraints.

I will not mourn my old designs. They did their part and did it well.

Now it's time for a new series of adventures.

...

Now it's time for a new series of adventures.

Exactly !!!

And that will add a lot of fun, still in a hurry to test the 1.0.5 update

Sounds like the update is coming along nicely.

On the engine fan/nozzle thing, I like the new model but agree this does limit real-life design possibilities. A solution would be to add gizmo's to the nozzle subpart, so you can rotate/offset it from the main turbine part. Roverdude does something similar with the new Mk3 tail ramp as I understand, so I'd imagine it won't be too much of a hassle to implement and this way you keep both the turbine and practical VTOL abilities (also please unnerf the Wheesley thrust at sea level a bit). Additionally, it would allow for changing the direction of the nozzle during flight.

Nathankell has seen few issues with his code in experimentals so far, and has shifted his attention to fixing ye olde bugs and filling in a few small holes in the code.

Awesome, now include a career + science overhaul and interesting planetary exploration and you might have a release candidate on you hands Also, could you make the external command seats crewable from the SPH/VAB and allow for any command module to be set as the default one? Thanks!

Edited November 4, 2015 by Yakuzi

All you VTOL whiners DO realize, that it's a purely optical change, right?

It will not affect your planes performance in any way. If you think spamming engine nozzles makes sense, you can keep doing it, the turbine will just look weird - otherwise not affecting anything.

Why don't you guys just hide the turbine in a fuselage or something?

Also, real life jets don't always have the nozzle aligned with the turbine - look at the Pegasus onthe Harrier. IMo, although it may look nice in the editor on some designs, turbines would just take away options without really adding any realism or options.

But also, in real life, there IS a turbine! Even in the Harrier. Think about it really, really hard. Would you actually prefer a dedicated, invisible, intractable "turbine" part?

TBH, I don't. I like PorkJets solution a lot, and VTOL'ers can just work around it.

Hopefully this means Squad have a proper VTOL system up their sleeves for 1.1's.

Maybe one with place anywhere VTOL Thrusters that respond to translation controls like RCS but raid their power from a turbine engine on the craft.

Anywho this Dev makes me happy either way.

All you VTOL whiners DO realize, that it's a purely optical change, right?
Also, real life jets don't always have the nozzle aligned with the turbine - look at the Pegasus on the Harrier.

But also, in real life, there IS a turbine! Even in the Harrier. Think about it really, really hard.

That's not what he's saying. Try reading his post really, really hard. Also, resorting to insulting people that design craft differently than you is not constructive to say the least. I'm sure we can figure out a compromise that will leave all parties (un)happy, read my post just above yours.

Edited November 4, 2015 by Yakuzi
